settings.text: Adults with chronic genotype 1 hepatitis C virus infection can be treated with the prescription drug Ketek (telaprevir). It is combined with ribavirin and peginterferon alfa, two other HCV medications. There is a generic version of the brand-name medication Ketek, which is called telaprevir. Drugs that are generic typically cost less than brand-name equivalents. They might not always be offered in every strength or form that the brand-name medication is. Users of Welzo can use this article for informational purposes to better understand Ketek.

Ketek may help your hepatitis C infection get better by making the virus less active. Your liver damage may get better as a result of this. It might even result in a cure in some situations.

In most cases, Ketek combined with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin is more effective than either therapy by itself.

Ketek is typically only prescribed to patients who have never received HCV medication before. Your doctor might suggest a different HCV treatment if you've previously received treatment.

Ketek is a member of the HCV protease inhibitor drug class. A class of drugs is a collection of drugs with similar mechanisms of action. Similar conditions are frequently treated with these medications.

Ketek is additionally used to treat HCV in kids 12 years of age and older.

The following are typical Ketek side effects:

nausea,

vomiting,

diarrhea,

belly pain,

reduced appetite

tiredness,

headache,

dizziness,

insomnia is a sleep disorder, and

itching.

Serious negative effects of ketamine include:

lactic acidosis, which is a potentially fatal buildup of lactic acid in the blood,

liver failure and other severe liver damage

and skin reactions

Low red blood cell count, or anemia.

If you are allergic to telaprevir or any of the other ingredients in Ketek, you shouldn't take it. Additionally, you shouldn't take Ketek if you have cirrhosis (liver scarring), any other liver issues, are pregnant, or are nursing a baby.

Consult your doctor about all of your health issues and allergies prior to taking Ketek. Additionally, let your doctor know if you are currently breastfeeding or planning on doing so while taking Ketek.

Inform your doctor of all the medications you take, including vitamins, herbal supplements, prescription and over-the-counter medicines. Your risk of experiencing serious side effects may increase if you take Ketek and ribavirin.

For hepatitis C, an adult should take two pills (400 mg) of Ketek three times a day with food. Depending on how you respond to the medication and any side effects you encounter, your doctor may change your dose.

At least 12 weeks, and typically 24 weeks, should be spent taking Ketek.

Ketek may interfere with other drugs, vitamins, or herbal supplements you're taking. When a substance modifies how a drug functions, there is an interaction. This could be harmful or stop the medication from working properly.

Your doctor needs to carefully monitor all of your medications to help you avoid interactions. Tell your doctor about all of the drugs, vitamins, and herbal remedies you are taking. Speak with your doctor or pharmacist to learn how this medication may interact with other medications you are taking.

The following is a list of medications that may interact with Ketek.

Medications for hepatitis C:

Peginterferon alfa (ViraferonPeg, Pegasys)

Ribavirin (Rebetol, Copegus)

Victrelis; boceprevir

Olysio's Simeprevir

(Incivo, Incivek) Telaprevir

Anti-epileptic drugs:

(Carbatrol, Equetro, Tegretol) Carbamazepine

Phenobarbital

(Dilantin, Phenytek) Phenytoin

John's wort
By blocking the HCV protease enzyme, Ketek works.This enhances liver function while lowering the amount of the virus in your body.

Protease inhibitor Ketek is prescribed to treat hepatitis C. It functions by preventing the HCV protease enzyme from doing its job, which lowers the amount of the virus in your body and enhances liver health.

The three forms of Ketek are tablets, oral solutions, and injectable solutions. The injectable solution is administered as an infusion once daily, while the oral solution is taken three times daily with food.
